entry.title: Down Payment Request Issue
entry.content:
Issue No 1

A Purchase Order (PO) has been created with Supplier A.

During DPR processing, the system allows the DPR to be posted against the same PO but with a different supplier (Supplier B).

The system does not restrict or validate the supplier mismatch and allows DPR posting.

The Purchase Order field must be mandatory during DPR creation.

Issue No 2

  1. We have created a Purchase Order with a value of INR 100.
  2. While posting the DPR, the system allows posting an amount greater than the PO value.
    The system only displays a warning message stating that the order value will be exceeded, but it does not block the posting.

While posting the DPR, the system allows posting more than the Purchase Order value.
The system is not throwing an error message; it only shows a warning that the order value will be exceeded.


We need this warning message to be changed to an error so that posting is blocked when the PO value is exceeded.

Thanks

Achyuta

entry.title: Re: Available stock mapping in go live project with MTO s...
entry.content:
Consider the below approaches

1. Manual Reassignment via Transfer Posting
Use Transfer Posting to move normal stock into sales order stock (special stock type E). Reference the sales order number during transfer so the system reclassifies the stock. This ensures the uploaded stock is now visible against the MTO order.

2. Backflush / Goods Issue Adjustments
For partially closed orders, check if WIP postings already exist. Perform goods issue adjustments to consume the uploaded normal stock into the production/WIP process. This way, the system balances the stock against the MTO requirement.

3. Custom Cutover Mapping
During Go-Live, some projects use custom mapping tables to link uploaded stock to open sales orders. Consultants may run a mass update program to reassign stock categories (normal ‚Üí MTO). This avoids manual postings for large volumes.

4. Production Order Settlement Alignment
If FG is already activated under MTO, ensure that production order settlement consumes the reassigned stock. Align the valuation class and account assignment so financial postings remain consistent.

5. Business Process Decision
If stock cannot be reassigned technically, consider closing old orders and creating new MTO orders linked to the uploaded stock. This is less elegant but sometimes cleaner for audit and reconciliation.

entry.title: Re: Update Ariba System Main IT contact
entry.content:
Hello customer,

Regarding your request to update the main IT contact for the Ariba system, kindly know the main IT contact person for the cloud system is indicated in the corresponding cloud contract, maintained by the SAP Order Management team.

If you need to change the main IT contact person for your Ariba system, you need to reach out to your SAP Account Manager. Your SAP Account Manager can check the contract information and provide you with the required assistance.

If you don't know who is the SAP Account Executive for your customer number xxxx, you may contact the CIC team per KBA 2626344. Then please send email to your account manager and provide your customer number, cloud product contract number (if you know it), and explain that you need to change the IT contact for the required product.

Since this matter relates to contracts, we at SAP Product Support are limited in the assistance we can provide. Your account manager will review the contract information and provide you with the necessary support.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: 8 Critical Pain Points of MCP in an Enterprise
entry.content:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is being hailed as the "USB port" for AI agents. But for the enterprise, it is currently a security "Wild West."

While MCP makes it easy to connect LLMs to data and tools, deploying it without a centralized gateway creates a fragmented environment where security policies are nearly impossible to enforce.

If you are moving AI agents from demo to production, here are 8 critical pain points:

  1. The Attribution Gap
    AI agents usually execute tools via service accounts. When a massive data export happens, your log shows "mcp-service-account" instead of the human employee who triggered it. This makes SOX and GDPR compliance impossible.

  2. Over-Privileged Access
    Most MCP setups are all-or-nothing. A user needing to view orders might accidentally inherit the ability to delete them because there is no granular, tool-by-tool authorization.

  3. No Central Kill Switch
    In a decentralized setup, there is no single control point. If a server is compromised, security teams must manually hunt and disconnect dozens of individual agent configurations while the breach spreads.

  4. The "Prompt-to-Delete" Risk
    Prompt injection is a real threat. Without human-in-the-loop gates, a cleverly worded prompt can trick an agent into executing high-risk actions like cleaning up a production database.

  5. Discovery Without Governance
    Currently, agents either see everything or nothing. We lack a middle ground where a user can discover a capability exists but must request formal permission before the agent can execute it.

  6. Cross-Tenant Contamination
    Without strict boundary enforcement, sensitive R&D or executive compensation data can leak into agents used by other departments, violating internal confidentiality.

  7. Forensic Nightmares
    Audit logs are scattered across dozens of servers in inconsistent formats. Correlating who did what and when after a breach takes weeks of manual work instead of minutes.

  8. Shadow AI Integrations
    Developers are already running local MCP servers on their laptops to test with production data. These bypass firewalls and leave zero audit trail, creating massive compliance holes.

The Model Context Protocol is the future of agentic workflows, but the direct connection model does not scale in a regulated environment. Enterprises need a centralized governance layer to enforce authentication and authorization before these agents are given the keys to the kingdom.

How is your team handling the security of AI tool-calling?

entry.title: Architecting MCP for the Enterprise
entry.content:
Architecting MCP for the Enterprise

In my previous post, I explained why deploying Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers through direct agent-to-server connections creates security and governance risks in enterprise environments.

This follow-up focuses on the architectural correction.

While working through the design of a centralized governance layer for MCP-based integrations, one conclusion became clear: MCP is not the problem, treating MCP as a point-to-point integration is.

The Architectural Gap

Most MCP deployments today follow a familiar pattern:

  • Agents connect directly to MCP servers

  • Tools execute using service accounts

  • Authorization, audit, and control are fragmented

This works for experimentation but breaks down once traceability, least privilege, auditability, and incident response become mandatory. Enterprises already solved this problem for APIs. MCP requires the same architectural discipline.

The Required Architectural Shift

The shift is toward a centralized control plane.

All MCP interactions should pass through a governance layer positioned between AI agents and MCP servers. This layer does not replace MCP, it standardizes how MCP is accessed and controlled.

How This Architecture Addresses the Key Pain Points

A centralized governance layer enables:

  • Identity attribution
    Every MCP action executes in the context of a real user identity, not a shared service account.

  • Least-privilege authorization
    Access is granted at the capability level, separating read, write, and destructive operations.

  • Centralized control and revocation
    MCP servers and permissions can be disabled instantly from a single control point.

  • Guardrails for destructive actions
    High-risk operations are denied by default and explicitly authorized.

  • Governed capability discovery
    Capabilities are visible, while execution remains controlled.

  • Tenant and domain isolation
    Consistent boundaries prevent cross-team and cross-tenant data exposure.

  • Centralized audit and forensics
    All MCP activity becomes queryable, not forensic.

  • Visibility into shadow AI usage
    A single governed access path makes MCP usage observable and controllable.

Technology-Agnostic by Design

This architecture aligns with established enterprise patterns:

  • Federated identity and access management

  • Policy-based authorization

  • Gateway or service-mesh enforcement

  • Centralized audit and observability

Technologies may vary. The architecture should not.

entry.title: incrementalMigrationJobNonLP failing intermittently with error related to 'MIGRATIONTOOLKIT_TF_TYPEI
entry.content:
We are using the opensource sap-commerce-db-sync(SAP/sap-commerce-db-sync: SAP Commerce extensions to perform table-to-table replication in single-directionally manner between two SAP Commerce instances or between SAP Commerce and an external database.) in our project to migrate data from hybris dB to target dB in SAP. We have the localized and non-localized cronjobs setup and scheduled to run twice a day. But it's been observed that the non-localized incremental migration job(incrementalMigrationJobNonLP) is going into error frequently with the below error.

org.springframework.jdbc.datasource.init.ScriptStatementFailedException: Failed to execute SQL script statement #2 of class path resource [sql/transformationFunctions/mssql-typeinfotable.sql]: CREATE TABLE MIGRATIONTOOLKIT_TF_TYPEINFO ( InternalCode NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, PK BIGINT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY (InternalCode) ); nested exception is com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: There is already an object named 'MIGRATIONTOOLKIT_TF_TYPEINFO' in the database.

The same goes to success upon rerun. We are seeing data inconsistencies between the source and target tables every now and then and presume that it is due to these frequent failures. Hence any help identifying the root cause would be appreciated.

entry.title: Issue with Cross-Order Staging Determination During PMR Creation in Embedded EWM
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

I am currently working on cross-order staging in an S/4HANA 2023 system with embedded EWM.

In my /SCWM/PSASTAGE, I have maintained both single-order and cross-order staging. For the relevant product group, the staging category is clearly set to cross-order (2). Also product group is also correctly assigned to the materials in the material master (Basic Data 2 view).

Out of the three materials involved:

AS-RM-PLASTIC-NYL   - Cross order

AS-RM-SEAL-RUB  - Single order

AS-RM-PLASTIC-PP - Cross order

Two materials are assigned to the cross-order product group

One material is assigned to single-order staging

The same cross-order product group is maintained in /SCWM/PSASTAGE, so from a configuration perspective, everything looks correct.

Next, I created a production order using these materials. The components are batch-managed, and all required details such as storage location and batch number are maintained correctly.

When I attempt to create the PMR, it does get created, but with an error. In the PMR in EWM, the system is unexpectedly treating the material as single-order staging, even though it is configured for cross-order staging.

Because of this, the system throws an error stating that Warehouse Process Type 3020 is not allowed for the document category.

 

When I debugged the issue, I found that:

The system is determining the staging method as ‚Äú3‚Äù (single-order staging) instead of cross-order

Based on this incorrect staging method determination, the system expects a picking process category. /SCWM/T333-TRART

However, 3020 is configured as a replenishment process type, which causes the validation to fail

So the actual root cause is not the warehouse process type itself, but the incorrect determination of the staging method. Since the system assumes single-order staging, all subsequent validations are executed accordingly, which leads to this error.

I was able to identify where the error is triggered, but I am not able to trace why the staging indicator is being determined incorrectly. I am trying to understand:

Which class or method is responsible for staging method determination during PMR creation

Why the system ignores the cross-order configuration and defaults to single-order staging in this case?

If anyone has insights into how PMR staging determination works internally, or knows the relevant function module or class/method, your guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you.
Kannan Chokkanathan.

entry.title: Guide to the Return STO Process in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

Reverse logistics is an integral part of any robust supply chain. Whether it's due to quality issues, excess stock, or a simple change in plans, the need to return materials from one plant to another is a common business requirement. In the world of SAP, this is managed through the Return Stock Transport Order (Return STO) process.

While the concept isn't new, its execution in SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public edition) with its Fiori-first methodology that makes the difference. This guide will walk you through the functional steps, highlight the key Fiori apps involved, and clarify the differences between the primary return scenarios.

Let's dive in!

What is a Return STO?

A standard Stock Transport Order (STO) is used to move articles / materials from a Supplying plant (A) to a Receiving plant (B). A Return STO simply reverses this flow. The plant that originally received the goods (i.e) Plant (B) now acts as the "Supplying" plant, sending the stock back to the original source Plant (A).

The key trigger for this process is a specific "Returns Item" indicator in the Purchase Order, which tells the system to handle the logistics in reverse.

The Core Scenarios for Return STOs

In S/4HANA Cloud Public release, the Return STO process can be broadly categorized into two main scenarios, each suiting different business needs.

Scenario 1: Simple Return (Without a Delivery Document)

This is the most straightforward method. It's ideal for returns over short distances or within the same campus, where formal shipping documentation isn't necessary. The entire process is managed within Inventory Management (MM-IM).


Process Flow:

  1. Create a Return Purchase Order (Manage Purchase Orders)
  2. Post a Goods Issue directly against the Purchase Order.
  3. Post a Goods Receipt at the receiving plant.

Key Characteristics & Apps:

  • No Shipping (LE-SHP) Integration: You do not create an outbound delivery.
  • Goods Movement: The process is a direct plant-to-plant transfer posting.
  • Key Fiori App: Post Goods Movement (MIGO)
    • You use this app to post the "Goods Issue" from the sending plant, referencing the Return PO. The system automatically uses Movement Type 161. This movement type simultaneously reduces stock at the sending plant and increases the "Stock in Transit" for the receiving plant.
    • The receiving plant then uses the same app to post the Goods Receipt, completing the process.

Scenario 2: Return with an Outbound Delivery

This process is typically covered under the Best Practices scope item 1P9 (Stock Transfer with Delivery),  is the more common and structured process, especially when goods are moving between geographically separate locations. It integrates with the Logistics Execution (LE) part of the system, allowing for proper shipping, picking, and transportation planning.

Process Flow:

  1. Create a Return Purchase Order (with the returns flag).
  2. Create an Outbound Delivery based on the PO.
  3. Pick the items for the delivery (if warehouse-managed).
  4. Post the Goods Issue from the delivery.
  5. Post the Goods Receipt at the receiving plant, referencing the delivery.

Key Characteristics & Apps:

  • Shipping (LE-SHP) Integration: The creation of an Outbound Delivery is a mandatory step.
  • Structured Process: Allows for better tracking, packing, and handling of the shipment.
  • Key Fiori Apps:
    • Create Purchase Order - Advanced (App id : F0842A): The starting point.
    • My Outbound Deliveries (or Create Outbound Deliveries - From Stock Transport Orders): Used to create the delivery document from the Return PO.
    • Post Goods Issue: You post the GI directly from the outbound delivery document, which uses Movement Type 671 (for a two-step transfer). This moves the stock into "Stock in Transit".
    • Post Goods Movement (MIGO): The receiving plant references the outbound delivery or PO to post the goods receipt, using Movement Type 161 to move stock from "Stock in Transit" to plant storage.

A Step-by-Step Walkthrough (Scenario 2: Return with Delivery)

Let's walk through the most common scenario to see the apps in action.

Step 1: Create the Return Purchase Order

  • App: Create Purchase Order - Advanced
  • Action:
    • Select the appropriate Purchase Order type for STOs.
    • Enter the receiving plant in the header (this is the plant the goods are going back to).
    • In the item details, enter the supplying plant (the plant sending the goods back).
    • Crucially, check the "Returns Item" checkbox on the item detail screen. This is what makes it a Return STO.
    • Save the PO.

Step 2: Create the Outbound Delivery

  • App: My Outbound Deliveries or Create Outbound Deliveries - From Stock Transport Orders
  • Action:
    • The system will show your Return PO as a shipping due list item.
    • Select the item and create the outbound delivery. The system automatically determines the correct delivery type based on your configuration.

Step 3: Post Goods Issue (PGI)

  • App: From within the Outbound Delivery document you just created.
  • Action:
    • If picking is required, you'll perform that step first.
    • Click "Post Goods Issue".
    • The system will post the goods movement in the background (Movement Type 671). You can check the stock status using the Stock - Single Material app, where you will see the quantity now in "Stock in Transit".

Step 4: Post Goods Receipt (GR)

  • App: Post Goods Movement
  • Action:
    • The receiving plant's clerk opens the app.
    • Select "Goods Receipt" and "Purchase Order" (or "Outbound Delivery").
    • Enter the Return PO number or the delivery number.
    • The system will pull in the data, including the correct Movement Type (161).
    • Post the document. The stock is now moved from "Stock in Transit" into the receiving plant's specified storage location (e.g., Unrestricted or Blocked stock). 

 Key Differences at a Glance
 

Feature

Scenario 1: Return without Delivery

Scenario 2: Return with Delivery

Core Process

Purely Inventory Management (IM)

Integrated with Logistics Execution (LE-SHP)

Key Document

Purchase Order

Purchase Order + Outbound Delivery

Goods Issue App

Post Goods Movement

My Outbound Deliveries (or related apps)

Goods Issue Mov. Type

161 (One-Step Transfer Posting)

671 (Two-Step Transfer to Stock in Transit)

Goods Receipt Mov. Type

(N/A - Part of the 161 movement)

161 (Receipt from Stock in Transit)

Use Case

Internal, short-distance transfers

Formal, long-distance, planned shipments

Final Thoughts

The Return STO process in SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public edition) is flexible, robust, and fully integrated into the Fiori landscape. The key is to understand your business requirement first: do you need the formality of a shipment, or is a simple inventory transfer sufficient? Once you've answered that, you can follow the corresponding app-driven path.

By leveraging the "Returns Item" indicator and the correct sequence of Fiori apps, you can manage your reverse logistics efficiently and with full visibility.

What are your experiences with Return STOs in the Public Cloud? Have you encountered any unique scenarios or have tips to share? Please leave your thoughts in the comments below!

entry.title: Chapter 1 || SAP Joule: The central nervous system for Business
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been listening to a couple of fascinating podcasts on SAP Joule, and I wanted to share a summary of what I found most informative:

It‚Äôs more than just a chatbot. Joule is an AI-powered co-pilot embedded across the entire SAP ecosystem. Think of it as a central nervous system for your enterprise. It connects different parts of your business, allowing information to flow smoothly so you get complete visibility of your data "under one roof." This enables leaders to make truly informed decisions.

üõ°Ô∏èWhat about Security?  It‚Äôs incredible that Joule can pull data from across the SAP landscape to give a holistic view, but the big question is always security. The answer lies in Access Control. Joule respects your existing security framework; if you don‚Äôt have permission to see certain data in the SAP system, Joule won‚Äôt be able to access it either. It operates entirely within your established guardrails.

üß†The Role of LLMs  People often ask what Large Language Models (LLMs) actually do in the context of Joule. LLMs are the "brain" that allows Joule to generate human-quality text, translate languages, and create content. Because these models are trained on massive datasets of code and business concepts, it‚Äôs like having access to a team of expert coders, analysts, and consultants at your fingertips.

‚ö°The Bottom Line  Joule uses NLP (Natural Language Processing) to understand us, Machine Learning to adapt and improve, and LLMs to generate creative, human-understandable output‚Äîall while being deeply integrated with SAP.

The Future is Here (2026 update!): With the SAP Joule + Microsoft 365 Copilot integration now live, the possibilities are endless. No more switching between apps! You can now leverage Microsoft 365 content, like emails, docs, and chats, directly within your SAP workflows.

SAP is innovating at an incredible pace. Let‚Äôs buckle our seatbelts and enjoy the ride in 2026!

entry.title: Re: Use of "Inventory in period" field in creation of CC...
entry.content:
Meaning of Inventory in Period field: This defines the cycle counting period in which the material is scheduled for inventory counting.

Usage: In cycle counting, materials are assigned to counting classes (A, B, C, etc.) with different frequencies (e.g., monthly, quarterly, yearly). The system uses the Inventory in Period field to determine when a material should be counted within the fiscal year. Example: If a material is assigned to cycle counting indicator ‚ÄúA‚Äù (monthly), and you enter Period 3, the system expects the material to be counted in the 3rd period of the fiscal year.

Impact is it controls scheduling of physical inventory documents. Ensures compliance with cycle counting rules. If left blank or incorrect, the material may not be picked up in the right cycle.


Meaning of Count Date field: This is the planned date on which the physical count will be performed.

Usage: When you create the physical inventory document, you specify the Count Date. This is the date the warehouse team will actually go and count the stock. It is also used for system checks ‚Äî e.g., postings after the count date may trigger warnings or adjustments.

Impact is it determines when the system expects the count to happen. Influences the freeze of stock movements (depending on configuration, stock may be blocked for posting during the count). Important for audit trail ‚Äî the count date is recorded and compared against the posting date of differences.

How they work together

  • Inventory in Period ‚Üí scheduling tool (when in the fiscal year the material should be counted).
  • Count Date ‚Üí operational tool (the exact calendar date when the count is executed).

Think of it like this:

  • Inventory in Period = ‚ÄúThis material should be counted in March.‚Äù
  • Count Date = ‚ÄúThe actual count will happen on March 15th.‚Äù

entry.title: creating a Variant in the screen (ME21N) where no data is displayed, or the Characteristic
entry.content:
We are facing an issue in ME21N (Create Purchase Order) related to Variant Configuration (VC), where the Characteristic Display is not visible or not showing any data after selecting a variant.

Issue Description

  • In ME21N, after creating or selecting a PO variant, the ‚ÄúCharacteristic Display / No Data‚Äù dropdown is not available, or it shows No Data.

  • Even though the material is VC-enabled and all configuration is maintained, characteristic values are not displayed in the PO.

  • Due to this, the variant-specific price is also not getting picked in the Purchase Order.

Business Scenario

  • Client requirement is to purchase configurable materials without any Sales Order dependency.

  • Example:

    • Material: Paint (VC-enabled)

    • Characteristics: Color

      • Green ‚Äì ‚Çπ120

      • Yellow ‚Äì ‚Çπ200

      • Black ‚Äì ‚Çπ50

  • All VC modeling, characteristics, classes, and pricing conditions are maintained correctly.

  • At the time of PO creation, the user should be able to select the color variant, and the price should be determined automatically based on the selected characteristic.

Current Problem

  • While creating the PO in ME21N, the Characteristic Display option is not visible / showing No Data.

  • Variant selection is not reflected, and variant-based pricing is not triggered.


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

Dear Team,

Good Day!

We are facing an issue in ME21N (Create Purchase Order) related to Variant Configuration (VC), where the Characteristic Display is not visible or not showing any data after selecting a variant.

Issue Description

  • In ME21N, after creating or selecting a PO variant, the ‚ÄúCharacteristic Display / No Data‚Äù dropdown is not available, or it shows No Data.

  • Even though the material is VC-enabled and all configuration is maintained, characteristic values are not displayed in the PO.

  • Due to this, the variant-specific price is also not getting picked in the Purchase Order.

Business Scenario

  • Client requirement is to purchase configurable materials without any Sales Order dependency.

  • Example:

    • Material: Paint (VC-enabled)

    • Characteristics: Color

      • Green ‚Äì ‚Çπ120

      • Yellow ‚Äì ‚Çπ200

      • Black ‚Äì ‚Çπ50

  • All VC modeling, characteristics, classes, and pricing conditions are maintained correctly.

  • At the time of PO creation, the user should be able to select the color variant, and the price should be determined automatically based on the selected characteristic.

Current Problem

  • While creating the PO in ME21N, the Characteristic Display option is not visible / showing No Data.

  • Variant selection is not reflected, and variant-based pricing is not triggered.

entry.title: Re: Select package size to solve 'Time out' Dump.
entry.content:
Hi Ronaldo 

I agree with Sandra Rossi that there is no way to cheat the timeout limit. You have to optimize the program.

But I don't understand when you say you make select without passing any key in where clause. As far as I can see you pass most of the fields for secondary indexes M, M1 and M2 (at least in my SAP system). 

Of course the keys are not used if the selection ranges so_mjahr, so_werks, so_date, so_matnr and so_bwart are all empty, but I couldn't imagine a scenario where it would be relevant to select all material documents without entering filters. I mean, all materials documents no matter when, no matter what, no matter where. That doesn't seem useful for anything.

Even without the timeout limit, the program would probably kill the whole SAP system because it would run out of memory. I just checked at one of my customers systems. This is a relative small company, but still the  MSEG table is more that 25 giga bytes (65 million rows). You wouldn't want to read that size of data into internalt table lt_mseg.

I don't know what you and your functional consultant are trying to achieve so maybe if you gave more details, we could advise if the requirement can be fulfilled at all.

Please also specify what version of SAP.

Kind regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: Re: Down Payment Request Issue
entry.content:
What is happening for issue 1 is the system allows you to create a DPR referencing a PO, but it does not validate whether the supplier in the DPR matches the supplier in the PO. Why because, in Public Cloud, standard validations are limited compared to on‚Äëpremise. The PO field in DPR is not hard‚Äëcoded as mandatory, and supplier consistency checks are not enforced by default.

Resolution options:

Check if there is a configuration option to make the PO reference mandatory in DPR creation. In some cases, you can enforce mandatory fields via Business Configuration (Field Control).

Use Custom Logic app to implement a validation in such a way that if PO is entered, validate that DPR supplier = PO supplier. If mismatch, raise error and block posting.

As a workaround, enforce this via workflow approval ‚Äî DPRs with mismatched suppliers are rejected.

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence Applied to Product Development in SAP Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly reshaping the landscape of product development, offering new ways to streamline processes, enhance collaboration, and drive innovation. Here‚Äôs how AI is making a tangible impact across the product development lifecycle: 

Optimizing Requirements Descriptions with SAP Business AI 

AI-powered text generation tools are simplifying the creation of descriptions for the requirements model. When users create requirements in the‚ÄØRequirements Management and Systems Modeling‚ÄØapp, SAP GenAI in IPD helps them improve the descriptions for their requirements in two ways: SAP GenAI can

  •  Enhance the text that is entered  

  • Come up with a short summary of a longer text.‚ÄØ 

The outcome? Requirements are described more quickly, precisely, and concisely, enabling users to gain a clearer understanding and facilitating more effective requirements management. 

Smarter Access to Product Documentation  

Managing and accessing product documentation is often a bottleneck. SAP‚Äôs AI Copilot Joule offers conversational access to product documentation, enabling quick and efficient information searches. It summarizes search results and provides links to relevant topics, saving time for administrators and end-users. Simplified access to documentation keeps teams informed and supports better decision-making throughout the product development lifecycle. This ensures that all stakeholders have the necessary knowledge to perform their roles effectively, leading to smoother and more efficient product development processes.‚ÄØ 

Digitizing Legacy Assets 

In industries reliant on legacy documents and drawings, AI is a game-changer. AI-driven tools can digitize old PDF drawings, convert them into accessible digital formats, and enrich them with business data and standardized naming conventions. This ensures that critical information is always available, reduces downtime, and improves maintenance processes. By transforming paper-based assets into digital resources, organizations preserve valuable knowledge and foster better collaboration. 

AI Enhancements in Document Summarization 

AI's role in industrial settings extends to document summarization, crucial for product development involving collaboration among design partners and suppliers. These stakeholders share numerous documents like PDF drawings and engineering designs, and quickly finding relevant information is a challenge. Large Language Models (LLMs) can generate concise summaries of uploaded documents, saving research and development teams valuable time.  

 

Using Joule, large documents can be easily summarized into shorter, more digestible sections. If needed, you can ask Joule to further refine the query result.  

Sounds Good? We will not stop there 

AI-Assisted Product Specification Search‚ÄØ 

Another AI feature that we will deliver in Q1 of 2026 is the AI-assisted product specification search: Product specifications are key to managing product data in a compliant, structured and well documented fashion, be it for discrete products or process industries and food products. The data stored in product specifications goes beyond ERP data sets, including data sets for physical, chemical, analytical product compositions as well as compliant, regulated or generic product data sets. All these data sets are highly configurable and individual per customer.  Depending on the size of the organization, a company may have thousands or even millions of specifications stored in its systems. The sheer volume of these specifications can make it challenging for individuals to find specifications which might need compliance or regulated changes, often turning what should be a simple search into a time-consuming task. Traditional search methods require exact property or attribute definitions which need to be matched correctly depending on the appropriate use case. This can be very time-consuming when dealing with complex properties and thousands of data sets that may be described in various ways across different documents. The use of AI can advance product specification searches tremendously. With the help of SAP Business AI search, users can query specifications in natural language, eliminating the need to understand intricate field names and parameters. This intuitive search capability quickly filters relevant specifications, providing necessary information without traditional search hassles ‚Äì a quality that proves particularly useful for new or unfamiliar users. The LLM-powered search combines contextual understanding, semantic search capabilities, synonym recognition and contextual filtering, all based on natural language queries. 

Grounding the search on customer data, the use of AI searches can ensure even more meaningful results that are highly relevant for your specific business use cases.  

The Road Ahead 

Integrating AI into product development is more than a technological upgrade‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic move toward operational excellence. By streamlining ideation, documentation, navigation, and asset digitization, AI empowers businesses to innovate faster and respond more effectively to market demands. As AI technology continues to evolve, its role in product development will only expand, offering new opportunities for efficiency, innovation, and growth 

For more details on how artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities can be leveraged to improve the product development process in SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD), check out the related Meet the Expert session. 

More Information / Additional Links‚ÄØ 

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our‚ÄØcommunity page‚ÄØto ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the‚ÄØPSCC_Enablement‚ÄØtag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts.‚ÄØ 

Follow me on LinkedIn and stay up-to-date to our latest enablement assets:‚ÄØlinkedin.com/in/annette-garcia-lorenzo

entry.title: SAP BTP - IS - How to prevent your integration architecture from becoming a Frankenstein landscape
entry.content:
Spoiler

Disclaimer: This article shares architectural lessons learned from real-world projects. It does not promote or discourage any specific vendor; the focus is on platform coherence, governance, long-term maintainability, and a homogeneous integration landscape.

I will not present negative points or direct comparisons between platforms, and any sensitive data is out of scope. The intention is to generate reflection within the audience.

I'm also not to speak about SAP BTP in its entirety, as that would be lying and is outside my area of competence and knowledge; I only explore SAP Integration Suite.

Introduction

This blog was not written based on slides or frameworks; it was based on my experience over several years since the emergence of SAP BTP and the consolidation of the SAP Integration Suite component.

Here I will present some truths from the thinking of an out-of-the-box SAP XI/PI/PO/CPI developer. I will present 3 scenarios; I do not see much sense in more than that, it will already be enough for the integration audience to understand what I am trying to explain, or guide, or look for a point of reflection.

When I talk about ‚Äúthinking outside the box,‚Äù I am not using a trendy term. I mean that if we limit ourselves to being mere technical executors of tickets‚Äîwhether in PI/PO or in SAP Integration Suite SAP CPI‚Äîwe will lose the overall vision of the whole. If our vision is reduced to connecting boxes, creating mappings, or writing pieces of code in Groovy or JavaScript, XML to JSON or JSON to XML conversion, we will be underutilizing both the platform and not exploring the full knowledge we have in between the external world and the SAP backend (ECC or S/4HANA ‚Äì on-prem or on-cloud).

Think big, think high, do not be afraid to express your opinion.

When you have knowledge and truly know what SAP BTP Integration Suite offers, you gain the necessary authority to talk on equal terms with architects ‚Äî and to help build environments that really make sense.

Let‚Äôs go to our interesting journey.

How I saw some Frankenstein architectures being born: three real cases

Throughout my career, I witnessed moments when tools ‚Äúwith more know-how‚Äù ended up complicating what should have been simple.Let‚Äôs be sincere and honest here: any platform or application, whether SAP or non-SAP, always has strengths and weaknesses. However, the benefits of homogenizing these architectures are very strong: lower customization, better support, unified teams.

Scenario 1: Wasted Potential
I must confess that in this first scenario, I really saw myself only as an SAP PI/PO/CPI consultant connecting little boxes, mappings, and others. I did not have the knowledge or the courage at that time to express my position, and I believe this may have worsened the definitions, but I took a lesson from it.

Everything was organized: rules, standards, development guidelines, design, and models. At the beginning of a migration to S/4HANA, external architects ignored what was already implemented. SAP BTP (SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì APIM and CPI) already existed, but they chose to neglect the investment or any larger decision and used only the minimum necessary.

APIM was completely excluded and SAP CPI was limited to standard pre-content packages with the minimum possible modification; another market platform took over the entire APIM framework and custom integrations. The result? The erosion of a strategy that was already winning.

Negative impacts:

  • Redundancy and Duplicate Costs: Maintenance of two integration platforms (BTP and a third-party tool) to perform functions that SAP Integration Suite was already designed to handle natively.
  • Operational Inefficiency: Managing security, logs, and monitoring in two different environments increases the workload of the teams.
  • Loss of Native Optimization: By ignoring the APIM layer and the full potential of CPI, the organization loses the ability to govern, and the ecosystem becomes increasingly difficult to govern.

Scenario 2: Imposition of External Architecture Patterns
In this case, a ‚Äúthree-layer architecture ‚Äì Intelligence Layer, Processing/Routing Layer, Delivery Layer‚Äù borrowed from a completely different ecosystem was imposed on SAP CPI. To keep this artificial construction standing, the solution turned into a tangle of hundreds of JMS queues.

Negative impacts:

  • Unnecessary Complexity and Latency: Each extra JMS hop adds processing overhead and potential failure points that would not exist in a flow optimized for CPI.
  • High Maintenance Debt: Troubleshooting requires tracing messages through dozens of queues, making root-cause analysis extremely difficult and slow.
  • Resource and Cost Exhaustion: Excessive use of JMS queues can lead to resource bottlenecks in the tenant, affecting the performance of other critical integrations and the high operational cost of keeping this complex structure running.

Scenario 3: Fragmented Teams and Tools
An organization adopted BTP in a fragmented way, using events and APIs; only SAP CPI was consolidated and very well structured in its usage. They split responsibilities among teams that did not communicate with each other. In the end, they increased costs and complexity, wasting the natural synergy of SAP BTP ‚Äì SAP Integration Suite.

Negative impacts:

  • Logic and Data in Silos: Without communication, teams frequently rebuild similar logic or connectors, leading to inconsistent data mappings in the same landscape.
  • Architectural Inconsistency: Different teams apply different security and naming standards, resulting in a ‚Äúpatchwork‚Äù ecosystem that is difficult to govern.
  • Integration Friction: The lack of synergy prevents the organization from effectively leveraging Event-Driven Architecture (EDA).

The Rise of Fragmented Integration Architectures (‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù Patterns)

I have seen organizations invest heavily in SAP BTP, only to leave these strategic assets idle while external tools, patterns, and ‚Äúborrowed architectures‚Äù are stitched together into what I call Frankenstein Architectures, where I already provided three examples I experienced: powerful in isolation, fragile together.

These environments rarely arise from a technical necessity; more often, they emerge from disconnected decisions, architectural bias coming from professionals less familiar with SAP integration ecosystems, or lack of communication with the front line‚Äîdevelopers specialized in SAP Integration Suite‚Äîor from uncritical reuse or following market trends that platform X or Y is better here or there, comparing applications instead of seeing homogeneity and the benefits for the final customer, thus using architectures designed for completely different ecosystems.

I am not saying it cannot be done or should not be done; different ecosystems can coexist as long as it is in a harmonious way. But when we talk about native integrations, add-ons, connectors, and others, SAP BTP ‚Äì SAP Integration Suite is definitely unbeatable when the backend is SAP, whether ECC or S/4HANA.

Figure 1: Frankenstein Architecture

The ‚ÄúLegacy Mindset‚Äù Trap: The True Obstacle to Innovation

We can discuss tools, vendors, and platforms all day long, but very little of this is really limited by technology. The biggest barrier between us and a good innovation experience is habit ‚Äî based on years developing legacy systems (‚Äúwe will not touch it, it is working, who developed it already left the company, there is no documentation‚Äù), stable but rigid architectures, with familiar but inflexible experiences, and primitive fears of change.

Many companies still think with the logic of on-premise integration landscapes from a decade ago. This mindset generates frustration: fear of the new, discomfort with unfamiliar paradigms, and, in most cases, a fundamental lack of technical understanding of what modern platforms really offer.

Treating SAP BTP as if it were an on-premise PI/PO is not a technological limitation, but a mindset limitation. When cloud-native services become only point replacements for legacy runtimes, their true potential is never reached.

Real innovation does require a mindset change. The question should no longer be ‚ÄúHow do I create this mapping?‚Äù, but instead:
‚ÄúShould this be a mapping? Should it be an event? An API? Or should it even exist in its current form?‚Äù

Without this transition, organizations repeat historical patterns in new terrain, bringing the limitations of the past into today‚Äôs technologies. The result is not modernization, but legacy running in the cloud.

The Voice of the SAP Integration Suite Consultant: You Are the Integration Bridge

An experienced, senior, or specialist integration consultant, with knowledge in EM / EAM / APIM / IA / CPI, should not be just a ticket executor or focused exclusively on project delivery. We must act as strategic advisors. Our responsibility is to position ourselves ‚Äî not to complain, but to help architects and business stakeholders make better decisions.

When technical expertise aligns with business objectives, ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) stops being a forgotten PDF and becomes a living instrument, capable of guiding projects to success.

We have already gone through several topics; now I would like to enter a topic that can help a lot, from a major SAP partner where one of its co-owners is one of the biggest influencers and who contributed for years to the SCN community, @MichalKrawczyk

Let‚Äôs talk about INT4 Shield, a tool that can help your company get out of this tangle of applications, the disconnected ecosystem that can be characterized as a Frankenstein architecture

Dismantling the Frankenstein Architecture in case of Multiples Platforms

The Int4 Suite (previously known as Int4 IFTT/Shield) is a test automation and service virtualization tool designed specifically for SAP ecosystems. It acts as an ‚Äúaccelerator‚Äù to dismantle the Frankenstein architecture and simplify complex migrations.

Image 2 ‚Äì Dismantling the Frankenstein Architecture

To bring integrations from external platforms back to SAP BTP, or migration from SAP PI/PO, the biggest fear is functional regression (breaking what already works).

Third-Party Virtualization: Int4 Shield can simulate the responses of those ‚Äúexternal platforms‚Äù that today hold the APIM framework and custom integrations. This allows you to develop on SAP BTP and test the end-to-end flow without needing the external system to be ready or available.
Parity Guarantee: You can capture the behavior of the external platform and validate whether the new implementation on SAP Integration Suite delivers exactly the same result, ensuring that the original ‚Äúwinning‚Äù strategy is restored without operational risks.

PI/PO Migration: The End of Manual Reverse Engineering

The scenario of migrating UDFs (User Defined Functions) and complex Java mappings without documentation is one of the biggest time and cost bottlenecks. Int4 Shield addresses exactly these points:

Payload Capture Automation

Instead of a consultant needing to manually extract payloads from production (which involves security and compliance risks), Int4 Shield automates the capture of real messages from the PI/PO production or QA environment. It creates a ‚Äútest case repository‚Äù based on real business data.

Comparative Tests (Side-by-Side)

Int4 Shield executes the mapping in the old PI/PO and, simultaneously, the new mapping in SAP Integration Suite (BTP).

Automatic Comparison: It compares the output XML/JSON of both. If there is a difference of a single cent or character due to a complex UDF, the tool points out exactly where the error is.
No Reverse Engineering: The consultant does not need to understand every line of legacy Java code. They need to ensure that Output A (Legacy) is equal to Output B (BTP). Int4 Shield validates this massively, testing hundreds of scenarios in minutes.

Resource and Time Reduction

Elimination of Manual Testing: The effort to manually test complex mappings is reduced by up to 80%.
Independence from Documentation: As the tool uses the real message behavior as the ‚Äúabsolute truth,‚Äù the lack of UDF documentation is no longer a critical blocker.

Summary of Technological Benefits

Manual ChallengeSolution with Int4 Shield
Payload ExtractionAutomated and secure capture of real messages.
UDFs/Java MappingsValidation by result comparison (Black-box testing).
Reverse EngineeringFocus on the final result, not the old code.
Frankenstein ArchitectureSecure validation of migration from external components to BTP.

Dismantling the Frankenstein SAP PI/PO mappings and others

The Figaf tool is from another the bigg influencers and who contributed for years to the SCN community, @daniel.graversen (specifically the Figaf DevOps Suite and its Migration Edition) is focused almost exclusively on the integration layer, serving as the go-to solution for migrations from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite (BTP).

While it is not a 'generic' migration tool for any external application (such as a legacy database or a non-SAP ERP), it facilitates the migration of the integration flows that connect those applications to the SAP ecosystem.

Figaf: Focus and Capabilities

Figaf acts as a DevOps and Migration accelerator. It doesn‚Äôt just move code; it attempts to "translate" legacy logic into the new BTP environment.

  • Automated Migration: Automatically converts PI/PO ICOs (Integrated Configuration Objects) into Cloud Integration (iFlows).
  • Logic Translation: Transforms complex Java/Mapping UDFs (User-Defined Functions) into BTP-compatible Groovy scripts.
  • Lifecycle Management: Offers tools for transports, Git versioning, and automatic documentation‚Äîareas where standard SAP BTP functionality can sometimes fall short.
  • Scope: Focused on SAP PI/PO, SAP Integration Suite (CPI), and API Management.

Perspective:

FeatureFigaf (Migration Edition/DevOps)Int4 Shield
Tool DNAFocused on Migration and DevOps. Helps create and move integration objects.Focused on Regression Testing. Ensures nothing broke after the change.
iFlow AutomationYes. Automatically creates iFlows and converts mappings.No. It tests what you have already migrated (manually or via Figaf).
Backend TestingLimited to the integration layer.Strong. Validates the final result within S/4HANA or ECC (e.g., if the IDoc generated the correct Sales Order).
Simulation (Mocking)Tests flows by sending messages.Simulates external systems. Allows testing without needing peripheral systems to be connected.
PlatformsSAP PI/PO and SAP Integration Suite.Multi-platform (Boomi, MuleSoft, WebMethods, etc.).

Both "migration PI/PO" and "dismantling Frankenstein landscape" can coexist ? 

Off course 

Which one to choose?

  • Choose Figaf if: You have hundreds of interfaces in PI/PO and want to automate their creation in BTP, saving months of manual development and Groovy scripting.
  • Choose Int4 Shield if: Your focus is Quality Assurance (QA) and you need to prove to the business that the "end-to-end" process (from the external system to the S/4HANA database) remains identical after the migration.

RISE with SAP and Clean Core: The Last Chance to Fix the Past

The RISE with SAP methodology is not only a path to move the backend to S/4HANA ‚Äî it represents a rare opportunity to rethink historical decisions, clean up excesses, and correct distortions that accumulated over the years. When we talk about Clean Core, the focus usually falls almost exclusively on the backend: excessive ABAP Z, direct core modifications, custom logic created to address momentary urgencies that became permanent.

This effort is correct, necessary, and inevitable, but there is a critical point that often stays out of the equation: the integration layer.

If the company is willing to revisit decades of customized developments in SAP ECC or S/4HANA, why not apply the same principle to the integration architecture?

Integration is not optional. It is essential for the business to function. It is where processes connect, data flows, partners integrate, and critical operations happen in real time.

Ignoring this layer during a RISE initiative is losing half of the transformation value.

The Clean Core concept should not stop at ABAP. It needs to extend to how integrations are designed, governed, and evolved. Keeping the core clean while fragmenting integration with multiple external tools, borrowed architectures, and misaligned standards creates a paradox: a modern backend supported by a chaotic integration.

SAP Integration Suite, within the SAP BTP ecosystem, exists exactly to absorb this complexity outside the core. APIs, events, message-oriented integrations, and B2B were designed so that the backend remains stable, standardized, and ready for continuous evolution. Breaking this logic, outsourcing native capabilities to external solutions without a clear strategic reason, goes in the opposite direction of what RISE and Clean Core propose.

The RISE moment is the right moment to visit, observe, and question:

  • Why does this integration exist in this way?
  • Why was this mapping created like this? Where is the documentation?
  • How are we going to migrate this tangle of integrations from SAP PI/PO, which has no documentation, to SAP CPI? Is this not the moment to evaluate what is worth migrating and what is worth rebuilding in a cleaner way?
  • Should this logic be in ABAP Z or outside the core?
  • Does this functionality already exist natively in SAP Integration Suite?
  • Are we really homogenizing the architecture or just replacing one fragmented architecture with another?

RISE with SAP offers the context, executive sponsorship, and organizational momentum that rarely happen in day-to-day work. It is exactly at this moment that structural decisions need to be made ‚Äî not only in the backend, but across the entire integration landscape.

Cleaning the core and ignoring integration is an incomplete transformation. Thinking Clean Core without Clean Integration is postponing known problems to a more expensive and more complex future.

True modernization happens when backend and integration evolve together, in a coherent, governed way and aligned with the business strategy.

Image 3 ‚Äì Rise and Clean core backend plus Integration refactoring

Spoiler
Spoiler
Disclaimer: The views expressed in this article are based on personal professional experience and do not represent SAP, its partners, or any affiliated organization.

Conclusion

I hope this reflection encourages Integration Consultants to think outside the box. It is vital that we are involved in strategic decisions and the application of the SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology).

We must act as strategic advisors, not just ticket executors. Our responsibility is to help architects and stakeholders make better decisions. Your opinion is not just a technical preference; it is a vital contribution to long-term maintainability. When we understand the full potential of the platform, we stop being "box connectors" and become the architects of a truly connected, clean future.

 Thank you.

Kind regards,

Viana.

entry.title: Scoped Roles in SAC
entry.content:
Hello experts,

I have the following problem in SAC and would be happy if someone could provide a solution on how to deal with it or vote for the change in the Customer Influence Program. This would really help us in the project: 

Name: Scoped Roles in SAC

Request ID: 363937

Link: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/363937

 
Please describe your improvement request:

Scoped roles (like in the Datasphere) should also be introduced in SAC so that permissions can be controlled more precisely in SAC.

It may also make sense to use spaces such as those in Datasphere to implement the requirements. If necessary, the spaces in SAC and Datasphere could then be mapped.

 

What is the opportunity/problem the request will address?

In SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), granting edit permissions for a folder effectively gives the user edit capabilities across the entire SAC environment. If that user also has access to multiple spaces in SAP Datasphere, they can view all data models because roles in SAC are assigned globally rather than at a granular level. This becomes particularly problematic when sensitive HR data exists in Datasphere, as such data should only appear in a shared story developed by the internal SAP department.

Example Scenario: A user in SAC should:

  • Have view-only permissions for the HR folder to view the Story
  • In another folder, ‚ÄúA,‚Äù be able to create their own stories using data from Datasphere Space A.

To access both spaces, the user needs a consume role in Datasphere for each space.
The problem: Once the user has edit rights in any folder, they can also view the HR data model because they have a edit permission from a different Folder, which should not be visible.

What is the expected benefit?

The added value is better control of permissions in the SAC and thus better self-service that can be offered.

Thank You and Regards 

Niels

entry.title: Re: Overhead Cost Calculation on WBS ‚Äì No Results Generated
entry.content:
The root cause is Overhead calculation only applies to primary cost postings that are eligible for overhead absorption. The costs you mentioned (FB60 vendor invoice postings, MM flow via PO ‚Üí GR ‚Üí IR) are direct postings of primary costs.By default, these postings are not marked for overhead calculation unless the cost element category is set correctly (e.g., primary cost elements that are included in the costing sheet base). The costing sheet base is defined to pick up those cost elements. If the costing sheet does not include the cost elements used in FB60/MM postings, the system will run the calculation but generate zero overhead.
Having said that, the issue is not with AVC or the calculation run itself, but with the costing sheet setup ‚Äî your current cost elements are not included in the overhead base, so the system calculates nothing.
